title: Chapter 9 – Lists, Tuples, and Dictionaries Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 9. Test your understanding of lists, tuples, and dictionaries.

questions.prompt: Which line correctly creates a list of hacker names?

byOptionId.a: This creates a tuple without brackets in some contexts, but it's not a list.
byOptionId.b: Correct – this is a list of three strings.
byOptionId.c: Curly braces without key:value pairs create a set, not a list.
byOptionId.d: Parentheses create a tuple, not a list.

options.label: Adds 'usb' to the end of the list.

explanations.overview: append adds a new item to the end of the list.

byOptionId.a: append does not replace items; it adds a new one.
byOptionId.d: append always changes the list by adding something.

questions.prompt: You have `player = {"name": "Leo", "score": 50}`. How do you get the score?

explanations.overview: Dictionary values are accessed by key using square brackets and the key string.

byOptionId.a: Dictionaries are not indexed by number by default.
byOptionId.b: This tries to call player like a function.
byOptionId.c: Correct – this looks up the value stored under the key 'score'.
byOptionId.d: Dot-notation like this is not how dicts work in plain Python.

questions.prompt: What is special about tuples compared to lists?

options.label: Tuples are always longer than lists.
Tuples cannot be changed after creation.

explanations.overview: Tuples are immutable; lists are mutable.

byOptionId.a: Tuples can store any types, not just numbers.
byOptionId.b: Length has nothing to do with the type.
byOptionId.c: Correct – once you create a tuple, its elements cannot be changed.

questions.prompt: You want to store a player's name and score together and look them up by name. Which structure is best?

explanations.overview: Dictionaries connect named keys to values, which is perfect for labeled data.

byOptionId.a: You would lose the scores if you only store names.
byOptionId.b: A tuple stores the pair but does not label the parts.
byOptionId.c: Correct – key 'name' and 'score' clearly label the values.
byOptionId.d: A single string is hard to work with in code.
